column6: dwarf]] of the royal line of [[Durin's folk]], the great-grandson of King [[Náin II]]. He was the son of [[Farin]] and the older brother of [[Gróin]].

column1: Fundin was most likely born in the [[Lonely Mountain]] and went into exile with his people after the attack by the [[Dragons
column2: Dragon]] [[Smaug]]. He fathered two sons, [[Balin]] and [[Dwalin]].

column1: Fundin was killed beneath the [[East-gate of Moria]] in the [[Battle of Azanulbizar]], the final conflict of the [[War of the Dwarves and Orcs]]: He was part of the first assault of the vanguard that was thrown back with loss, and was driven into a wood by lake [[Mirrormere]].
He was slain there along with his kinsman [[Frerin]], and many others.  After the battle his body was burned on a wooden pyre along with the rest of the [[Burned Dwarves
Years later, his sons, as members of [[Thorin and Company]], were involved with the [[Quest of Erebor
column2: regaining of Lonely Mountain]]. [[Roäc]] recognised Balin as the son of Fundin.<ref>{{H

column1: ''Fundin'' is one of the dwarf names found in the [[Völuspá]]. <ref>{{HM
column2: AH}}, p. 316</ref> His name means "Found".<ref>Chester Nathan Gould, "Dwarf-Names: A Study in Old Icelandic Religion", published in ''Publications of the Modern Language Association of America'', Vol 44 (1929), issue #4, pp. 939-967</ref>
